ChatGPT said:

Your code is mostly correct and well-structured. You've built a solid Send component that allows:

  • Exporting an invoice in PDF, DOCX, or PNG formats.

  • Sharing it across a wide range of social platforms.

  • Dynamically rendering UI based on the selected export type.

However, there are a few bugs, improvements, and potential issues to address:

✅ ✅ Correct and Working Areas

  • Usage of html2canvas, jsPDF, docx, and file-saver is valid.

  • Dynamic switching of formats (PDF, DOCX, PNG).

  • Social media sharing logic with fallback if no format selected.

  • Proper usage of React useState and props.

  • Dynamic styles for selected export button.

❗ Issues & Fixes

1. 🔴 uploadFile doesn't return the uploaded file URL

Issue:

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  ...
  const data = await response.json();
  console.log("Upload successful:", data);
};

You're logging the upload result but not returning anything, so this will break sharing functionality.

Fix:

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  ...
  const data = await response.json();
  return data.fileUrl; // or the correct field returned from your backend
};

2. ⚠️ Incomplete generateBlobByFormat for DOCX

js
if (format === "docx") {
  const doc = new Document({
    sections: [{ children: [new Paragraph("...")] }],
  });
  return await Packer.toBlob(doc);
}

You’re returning a placeholder DOCX, not using your actual exportDOCX logic.

Fix: Refactor exportDOCX() to support blob generation or move content creation logic into a shared helper function used by both exportDOCX() and generateBlobByFormat().

3. ⚠️ setInvoiceURL is unused

You're initializing invoiceURL state, logging it, but never updating it.

Fix (optional): If needed for display or reuse later:

js
const url = await uploadFile(blob, getDownloadFileName());
setInvoiceURL(url);

4. 🔁 Redundant addSection() in exportDOCX()

You're calling:

js
const doc = new Document({ sections: [...] });
doc.addSection({ children: docContent });

This adds the same section twice.

Fix: Remove doc.addSection(...) since you're already passing sections to the constructor.

5. ⚠️ Minor style/logic improvements

  • Consider disabling the "Download" button unless a format is selected.

  • Add loading indicators or error handling for the async file generation and upload steps.

✅ Suggestions (optional)

  • Replace the repetitive <img onClick={...} /> for each platform with a map() function and array of configs.

  • Add support for progress/loading state during file generation and upload.

Would you like me to help refactor any part of this for clarity or reuse (like sharing table logic between exportDOCX and generateBlobByFormat)?

jsx
import React, { useState } from "react";
import "./send.css";
import jsPDF from "jspdf";
import html2canvas from "html2canvas";
import { saveAs } from "file-saver";
import {
  Document,
  Packer,
  Paragraph,
  Table,
  TableRow,
  TableCell,
  AlignmentType,
  WidthType,
} from "docx";

// ICONS
import DownloadIcon from "../assets/Download_Icon.png";
import WhatsappIcon from "../assets/whatsapp_Icon.png";
import FacebookIcon from "../assets/facebook_Icon.png";
import GmailIcon from "../assets/gmail_Icon.png";
import SMSIcon from "../assets/SMS_Icon.png";
import DiscordIcon from "../assets/discord_Icon.png";
import LinkedinIcon from "../assets/linkedin_Icon.png";
import MailIcon from "../assets/mail_Icon.png";
import MessengerIcon from "../assets/messenger_Icon.png";
import SnapchatIcon from "../assets/Snapchat_Icon.png";
import PinterestIcon from "../assets/pinterest_Icon.png";
import SkypeIcon from "../assets/skype_Icon.png";
import RedditIcon from "../assets/reddit_Icon.png";
import TelegramIcon from "../assets/telegram_Icon.png";
import TumblrIcon from "../assets/tumblr_Icon.png";
import XIcon from "../assets/X_Icon.png";

export default function Send({ data, refTarget }) {
  const [format, setFormat] = useState("");

  const getDownloadFileName = () =>
    `invoice-${data.invoiceNumber || "null"}.${format || "file"}`;

  const createDOCXDocument = () => {
    const tableRows = [
      new TableRow({
        children: ["Item", "Qty", "Unit Price", "Total Price"].map(
          (text) =>
            new TableCell({
              width: { size: 25, type: WidthType.PERCENTAGE },
              children: [new Paragraph(text)],
            })
        ),
      }),
      ...data.items.map(
        (item) =>
          new TableRow({
            children: [
              new TableCell({
                children: [new Paragraph(item.description || "-")],
              }),
              new TableCell({
                children: [new Paragraph(String(item.Qty || 0))],
              }),
              new TableCell({
                children: [new Paragraph(`₹${item.Unit_price || 0}`)],
              }),
              new TableCell({
                children: [new Paragraph(`₹${item.Total_price || 0}`)],
              }),
            ],
          })
      ),
    ];

    return new Document({
      sections: [
        {
          children: [
            new Paragraph({
              text: "INVOICE",
              heading: "Heading1",
              alignment: AlignmentType.CENTER,
            }),
            new Paragraph({
              text: data.senderCompanyAddress || "__________",
              alignment: AlignmentType.CENTER,
            }),
            ...[
              `Invoice Number: ${data.invoiceNumber || "__________"}`,
              `Company Code: ${data.companyCode || "__________"}`,
              `Project Name: ${data.projectName || "__________"}`,
              `Issue Date: ${data.issueDate || "__________"}`,
              `Due Date: ${data.dueDate || "__________"}`,
            ].map(
              (txt) =>
                new Paragraph({
                  text: txt,
                  spacing: { after: 100 },
                })
            ),
            new Paragraph({
              text: "Items:",
              heading: "Heading3",
              spacing: { after: 120 },
            }),
            new Table({
              width: { size: 100, type: WidthType.PERCENTAGE },
              rows: tableRows,
            }),
            ...[
              `Subtotal: ₹${data.subTotal}`,
              `Tax (12%): ₹${data.tax}`,
              `Discount: ₹0.00`,
              `Total Amount: ₹${data.total}`,
            ].map(
              (txt) =>
                new Paragraph({
                  text: txt,
                  alignment: AlignmentType.RIGHT,
                  spacing: { after: 80 },
                })
            ),
            new Paragraph({
              text: "Client Details:",
              heading: "Heading3",
              spacing: { after: 100 },
            }),
            ...[
              `First Name: ${data.firstName || "__________"}`,
              `Last Name: ${data.lastName || "__________"}`,
              `Email: ${data.email || "__________"}`,
              `Address: ${data.address || "__________"}`,
              `State/Country: ${data.country || "__________"}`,
              `Pin Code: ${data.pinCode || "__________"}`,
              `Contact: ${data.contact || "__________"}`,
              `Payment Mode: ${data.paymentMode || "__________"}`,
              `Notes: ${data.notes || "__________"}`,
            ].map((txt) => new Paragraph({ text: txt })),
          ],
        },
      ],
    });
  };

  const exportDOCX = async () => {
    const doc = createDOCXDocument();
    const blob = await Packer.toBlob(doc);
    saveAs(blob, getDownloadFileName());
  };

  const exportPDF = async () => {
    const canvas = await html2canvas(refTarget.current);
    const imgData = canvas.toDataURL("image/png");
    const pdf = new jsPDF("landscape", "mm", "a4");
    pdf.addImage(imgData, "PNG", 0, 0, 297, (canvas.height * 297) / canvas.width);
    pdf.save(getDownloadFileName());
  };

  const exportPNG = async () => {
    const canvas = await html2canvas(refTarget.current);
    canvas.toBlob((blob) => blob && saveAs(blob, getDownloadFileName()));
  };

  const generateBlobByFormat = async () => {
    if (format === "pdf") {
      const canvas = await html2canvas(refTarget.current);
      const pdf = new jsPDF("landscape", "mm", "a4");
      const imgData = canvas.toDataURL("image/png");
      pdf.addImage(imgData, "PNG", 0, 0, 297, (canvas.height * 297) / canvas.width);
      return pdf.output("blob");
    } else if (format === "png") {
      const canvas = await html2canvas(refTarget.current);
      return new Promise((resolve) => canvas.toBlob(resolve));
    } else if (format === "docx") {
      const doc = createDOCXDocument();
      return await Packer.toBlob(doc);
    }
    return null;
  };

  const uploadFile = async (file) => {
    const formData = new FormData();
    formData.append("file", file);
    try {
      const response = await fetch("http://localhost:5000/upload", {
        method: "POST",
        body: formData,
      });
      const result = await response.json();
      return result.fileUrl || null;
    } catch (error) {
      console.error("Upload failed:", error);
      return null;
    }
  };

  const handleSocialShare = async (platform) => {
    const blob = await generateBlobByFormat();
    if (!blob) return alert("Please select a format first.");
    const fileURL = await uploadFile(blob);
    if (!fileURL) return alert("File upload failed.");

    const encodedURL = encodeURIComponent(fileURL);
    const shareTexts = {
      whatsapp: `https://wa.me/?text=${encodedURL}`,
      facebook: `https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=${encodedURL}`,
      gmail: `mailto:?subject=Invoice&body=Invoice Link: ${fileURL}`,
      sms: `sms:?body=Invoice: ${fileURL}`,
      discord: `https://discord.com/channels/@me`,
      linkedin: `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${encodedURL}`,
      mail: `mailto:?subject=Invoice&body=Invoice Link: ${fileURL}`,
      messenger: `https://www.messenger.com/t`,
      snapchat: `https://www.snapchat.com/`,
      pinterest: `https://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=${encodedURL}`,
      skype: `https://web.skype.com/share?url=${encodedURL}`,
      reddit: `https://www.reddit.com/submit?url=${encodedURL}`,
      telegram: `https://t.me/share/url?url=${encodedURL}`,
      tumblr: `https://www.tumblr.com/widgets/share/tool?canonicalUrl=${encodedURL}`,
      twitter: `https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=${encodedURL}`,
    };

    const shareLink = shareTexts[platform];
    if (!shareLink) return alert("Unsupported platform.");
    window.open(shareLink, "_blank");
  };

  const handleExportClick = () => {
    if (format === "pdf") exportPDF();
    else if (format === "docx") exportDOCX();
    else if (format === "png") exportPNG();
    else alert("Please select a format.");
  };

  return (
    <div className="Send_container">
      <div className="box-One">
        <div className="box-One_subbox1">
          <div>
            <img src={DownloadIcon} alt="Download" onClick={handleExportClick} />
            <p id="para1">Download</p>
          </div>
          <p id="para2">
            Export invoices in PDF, DOCX, or PNG, or share them directly on social platforms.
          </p>
        </div>
      </div>

      <div className="Buttons">
        {["pdf", "docx", "png"].map((type) => (
          <span
            key={type}
            className={type}
            onClick={() => setFormat(type)}
            style={{
              backgroundColor: format === type ? "rgb(228, 58, 92)" : "rgb(53, 51, 51)",
            }}
          >
            {type.toUpperCase()}
          </span>
        ))}
      </div>

      <div className="img_section">
        {[WhatsappIcon, FacebookIcon, GmailIcon, SMSIcon, DiscordIcon, LinkedinIcon, MailIcon, MessengerIcon, SnapchatIcon, PinterestIcon, SkypeIcon, RedditIcon, TelegramIcon, TumblrIcon, XIcon].map((icon, i) => {
          const platforms = [
            "whatsapp", "facebook", "gmail", "sms", "discord",
            "linkedin", "mail", "messenger", "snapchat", "pinterest",
            "skype", "reddit", "telegram", "tumblr", "twitter"
          ];
          return (
            <img
              key={i}
              src={icon}
              alt={`${platforms[i]}Icon`}
              onClick={() => handleSocialShare(platforms[i])}
            />
          );
        })}
      </div>
    </div>
  );
}

The error message you're getting:

bash
POST http://localhost:5000/upload net::ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED
Upload failed: TypeError: Failed to fetch

means that your frontend is trying to send a file to your backend (http://localhost:5000/upload), but there's no server running on that port, or it's refusing the connection.

✅ Here's how to fix it:

Option 1: Set up a backend server to handle the upload

You can use a simple Express.js server to handle file uploads using multer.

📦 Example server.js:

js
const express = require("express");
const cors = require("cors");
const multer = require("multer");
const path = require("path");
const fs = require("fs");

const app = express();
const PORT = 5000;

app.use(cors());
app.use(express.static("uploads"));

// Set up storage for uploaded files
const storage = multer.diskStorage({
  destination: (req, file, cb) => {
    const dir = "./uploads";
    if (!fs.existsSync(dir)) fs.mkdirSync(dir);
    cb(null, dir);
  },
  filename: (req, file, cb) => {
    cb(null, `${Date.now()}-${file.originalname}`);
  },
});

const upload = multer({ storage });

// Upload route
app.post("/upload", upload.single("file"), (req, res) => {
  if (!req.file) return res.status(400).json({ error: "No file uploaded" });

  const fileUrl = `http://localhost:${PORT}/${req.file.filename}`;
  res.json({ fileUrl });
});

// Start server
app.listen(PORT, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on http://localhost:${PORT}`);
});

🧪 To Run the Backend:

  1. Make sure you have Node.js installed.

  2. Create a server.js file with the above code.

  3. Run this in the terminal:

bash
npm init -y
npm install express multer cors
node server.js

Option 2: Use a cloud service (like Cloudinary, S3)

If you don’t want to manage file uploads locally, you can use a cloud file host and update the uploadFile() function accordingly.

1. Check Your Routes Configuration

Check if your server.js file includes any routes that involve dynamic parameters, such as:

js

  // Handle request
});

If there is any route like this, make sure it's defined correctly. The path-to-regexp package requires parameters to be explicitly named (e.g., :id in the example above).

2. Check Your Dependencies

It’s possible that one of your dependencies is causing this issue. The error might not even be in your own code but in a dependency that relies on path-to-regexp. You can try the following:

Your server code looks mostly correct for handling file uploads and downloads. However, based on the error you're facing (the path-to-regexp error), there may be an issue with the routing or other configurations. I'll break it down into key steps and suggest some improvements.

Step-by-Step Explanation

  1. File Upload (/upload POST route)

    • The code uses upload.single("file") to handle the file upload. Make sure that you have set up multer correctly for handling file uploads.

    • After the file is uploaded, it stores the file path and timestamp in the files object, and responds with a unique file ID (using uuidv4()).

  2. File Download (/download/:fileId GET route)

    • This route retrieves the fileId from the URL and checks if the file exists in the files object.

    • If the file exists and is available on the server, it sends the file for download. After the file is downloaded, it deletes it from the server.

Check for Common Issues and Fixes

1. Ensure multer is Installed and Configured

Make sure you have multer properly configured to handle file uploads. Here’s a quick example:

bash
npm install multer

Then configure multer in your server code:

js
const multer = require("multer");
const upload = multer({ dest: "uploads/" }); // Store files in the "uploads" folder

2. Ensure the uuid Package is Installed

If you're using uuidv4() to generate unique file IDs, make sure the uuid package is installed:

bash

Then import it correctly in your code:

js
const { v4: uuidv4 } = require("uuid");

3. Ensure files Object is Defined

Ensure the files object is initialized properly at the top of your server code:

js
const files = {}; // This object will store file data (filePath, timestamp)

4. Check Route Parameters for path-to-regexp

The error you encountered, path-to-regexp error, is likely due to how the route parameters are defined. In your /download/:fileId route, ensure the dynamic parameter :fileId is used correctly.

js
app.get("/download/:fileId", (req, res) => {
  const fileId = req.params.fileId;
  // Rest of the code...
});

This is correct, but if you’re still seeing the error, check if any routes are incorrectly configured with parameters.

5. Check for File Existence Before Download

Make sure that the file exists before attempting to send it for download:

js
if (fs.existsSync(filePath)) {
  res.download(filePath, (err) => {
    if (err) {
      res.status(500).send("Error downloading file");
    }

    // File has been downloaded, delete it from the server
    fs.unlinkSync(filePath);
    delete files[fileId];
  });
} else {
  res.status(404).send("File not found or expired");
}

6. Ensure Correct Error Handling

Your error handling looks good, but I’d recommend making sure you're logging any errors for debugging purposes. Here’s an improved version of the app.get("/download/:fileId") route with additional logging for errors:

js
app.get("/download/:fileId", (req, res) => {
  const fileId = req.params.fileId;
  
  if (!files[fileId]) {
    console.error(`File with ID ${fileId} not found in records.`);
    return res.status(404).send("File not found or expired");
  }

  const filePath = files[fileId].filePath;

  // Check if the file exists
  if (fs.existsSync(filePath)) {
    res.download(filePath, (err) => {
      if (err) {
        console.error("Error downloading file:", err);
        res.status(500).send("Error downloading file");
      }

      // File has been downloaded, delete it from the server
      fs.unlinkSync(filePath);
      delete files[fileId];
    });
  } else {
    console.error(`File at path ${filePath} does not exist.`);
    res.status(404).send("File not found or expired");
  }
});

Final Check

  • Node.js Version: Make sure you're using a compatible version of Node.js.

  • File Path Issues: If you're storing the file path, ensure that the file path you're setting is correct, especially for Windows-based paths (if you're working on Windows).

  • Permissions: Ensure your uploads/ directory has the correct write permissions.

Full Example

Here’s how the full server code should look after addressing the issues:

js
const express = require("express");
const multer = require("multer");
const fs = require("fs");
const path = require("path");
const { v4: uuidv4 } = require("uuid");

const app = express();
const port = 5000;

// Initialize in-memory file storage
const files = {};

// Set up multer to store files in the "uploads" folder
const upload = multer({ dest: "uploads/" });

// POST route for file upload
app.post("/upload", upload.single("file"), (req, res) => {
  if (!req.file) {
    return res.status(400).send("No file uploaded");
  }

  // Generate a unique ID for the file and store its path and upload time
  const fileId = uuidv4();

  files[fileId] = {
    filePath: path.join(__dirname, req.file.path),
    timestamp: Date.now(),
  };

  // Respond with the file ID
  res.json({
    fileId,
  });
});

// GET route for file download by fileId
app.get("/download/:fileId", (req, res) => {
  const fileId = req.params.fileId;

  if (!files[fileId]) {
    console.error(`File with ID ${fileId} not found in records.`);
    return res.status(404).send("File not found or expired");
  }

  const filePath = files[fileId].filePath;

  // Check if the file exists
  if (fs.existsSync(filePath)) {
    res.download(filePath, (err) => {
      if (err) {
        console.error("Error downloading file:", err);
        res.status(500).send("Error downloading file");
      }

      // File has been downloaded, delete it from the server
      fs.unlinkSync(filePath);
      delete files[fileId];
    });
  } else {
    console.error(`File at path ${filePath} does not exist.`);
    res.status(404).send("File not found or expired");
  }
});

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on http://localhost:${port}`);
});

Conclusion

  1. Ensure that your multer and uuid packages are installed and configured properly.

  2. Double-check the file paths, especially when working on different operating systems (like Windows).

  3. Use console.error to log more information for debugging.

  4. Make sure you’re using the correct routing syntax for Express (:fileId).

This should address most of the issues you're facing with the server. If the error persists, feel free to share more details, and I’ll assist you further.

Your Send component seems generally well-structured, with several features for exporting invoices in different formats (PDF, DOCX, PNG) and sharing them on social platforms. However, there are a few points to review and optimize, which might help you ensure it works as expected.

Key Observations & Improvements

  1. exportDOCX and createDOCXDocument Functions:

    • The createDOCXDocument function is generating the DOCX file properly with the required data (invoice items, company details, etc.), so that's fine.

    • In the exportDOCX function, you're using Packer.toBlob(doc) to convert the DOCX document into a blob and then saving it via saveAs(). This should work fine.

  2. PDF Generation:

    • In exportPDF, you're using html2canvas to create a canvas from the refTarget and then adding it to a PDF. This is also correct.

    • Make sure that refTarget is a proper reference (useRef) pointing to the element you want to capture as an image for the PDF.

  3. PNG Export:

    • In exportPNG, the PNG file is also being generated from the same refTarget using html2canvas and saved via saveAs(). This looks correct.

  4. Social Sharing (handleSocialShare):

    • This function generates URLs for sharing on social media. It's generally well-constructed. However, make sure that the uploadFile function is correctly uploading the file to your server, and that it returns the fileUrl that can be used for sharing.

    • You might want to improve the user experience by providing feedback (loading states or error messages) to the user while the file is being uploaded or shared.

  5. Dynamic Rendering of Social Icons:

    • You're dynamically rendering a list of social media icons, which is great. The only thing I'd suggest is making sure that the corresponding social media platforms are handled correctly in the shareTexts object (you've done this part well).

  6. Format Selection & Export Handling:

    • The format buttons (pdf, docx, png) are set up correctly. You handle each format with a corresponding function, but you might want to add more visual feedback (like highlighting the selected format) or disable the buttons if the user hasn't selected one.

Potential Issues & Fixes

  1. Error Handling for Upload/Export:

    • The uploadFile function handles the file upload to the server, but you're just alerting errors. It would be nice to add better error handling, e.g., loading indicators, messages, or retries in case of failures.

    • Consider displaying a loading state or feedback while the file is being uploaded or generated for social sharing.

  2. Blob Generation by Format:

    • generateBlobByFormat is a good helper for generating the blob based on the selected format (PDF, PNG, DOCX), but it's not clear how the file is being uploaded (it seems you're passing the blob directly, but you might want to double-check if it's correctly uploaded).

    Also, make sure you call handleSocialShare only when the upload succeeds. You’re relying on uploadFile(blob) which is asynchronous, but you don't seem to be waiting for the upload completion before attempting to share the file.

  3. Social Media Share Links:

    • When sharing the file URL on social media platforms, ensure that the URL (fileURL) returned from the server is properly encoded. It looks like you are already doing this, so this part should work fine as long as the upload process is successful.

  4. Styling and Layout:

    • Since you're rendering the icons dynamically and using inline styles for some buttons, ensure the layout is responsive and visually appealing across different screen sizes.

  5. Optional: Add Loading Indicators

    • It would be helpful to add a loading spinner or status indicator when the file is being generated or uploaded.

Revised handleSocialShare and uploadFile Functions

Here’s a small improvement to better handle file upload before sharing:

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  const formData = new FormData();
  formData.append("file", file);
  try {
    const response = await fetch("http://localhost:5000/upload", {
      method: "POST",
      body: formData,
    });
    const result = await response.json();
    return result.fileUrl || null;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Upload failed:", error);
    return null;
  }
};

const handleSocialShare = async (platform) => {
  const blob = await generateBlobByFormat();
  if (!blob) return alert("Please select a format first.");
  
  // Show a loading state
  alert("Uploading file...");

  const fileURL = await uploadFile(blob);
  if (!fileURL) return alert("File upload failed.");

  const encodedURL = encodeURIComponent(fileURL);
  const shareTexts = {
    whatsapp: `https://wa.me/?text=${encodedURL}`,
    facebook: `https://www.facebook.com/sharer/sharer.php?u=${encodedURL}`,
    gmail: `mailto:?subject=Invoice&body=Invoice Link: ${fileURL}`,
    sms: `sms:?body=Invoice: ${fileURL}`,
    discord: `https://discord.com/channels/@me`,
    linkedin: `https://www.linkedin.com/sharing/share-offsite/?url=${encodedURL}`,
    mail: `mailto:?subject=Invoice&body=Invoice Link: ${fileURL}`,
    messenger: `https://www.messenger.com/t`,
    snapchat: `https://www.snapchat.com/`,
    pinterest: `https://pinterest.com/pin/create/button/?url=${encodedURL}`,
    skype: `https://web.skype.com/share?url=${encodedURL}`,
    reddit: `https://www.reddit.com/submit?url=${encodedURL}`,
    telegram: `https://t.me/share/url?url=${encodedURL}`,
    tumblr: `https://www.tumblr.com/widgets/share/tool?canonicalUrl=${encodedURL}`,
    twitter: `https://twitter.com/intent/tweet?url=${encodedURL}`,
  };

  const shareLink = shareTexts[platform];
  if (!shareLink) return alert("Unsupported platform.");
  window.open(shareLink, "_blank");
};

Conclusion

Overall, your code is on the right track, and with a few improvements in error handling and feedback, it should be ready to go. The logic for exporting files, sharing on social media, and generating invoices is well-organized. Just ensure you have robust error handling, clear user feedback, and testing with your backend file upload endpoint.

ChatGPT said:

If you're encountering a "File upload failed!" error when attempting to share a file via WhatsApp, there are several potential causes and corresponding solutions to consider:

📁 1. File Size Limitations

WhatsApp imposes maximum file size limits:​TechYouLike+1Heltar+1

  • Videos: Up to 16 MB

  • Images: Up to 10 MB​TechYouLike+1Reddit+1

If your file exceeds these limits, it cannot be uploaded. You can compress the file using tools like TinyPNG for images or HandBrake for videos.​Heltar

🗂️ 2. Unsupported File Formats

Ensure that the file format is supported by WhatsApp. Commonly supported formats include:​TechYouLike+4Heltar+4Stack Overflow+4

  • Images: JPEG, PNG, GIF

  • Videos: MP4, MKV, MOV

  • Documents: PDF, DOCX, XLSX​Guiding Tech

If your file is in an unsupported format, consider converting it to a compatible one.​Guiding Tech+1Heltar+1

🔐 3. File Permissions

The file must be accessible to other applications. If it's stored in a private or restricted directory, WhatsApp may not have permission to access it. Ensure the file is in a public directory and that WhatsApp has the necessary permissions to access storage.​Stack Overflow

🌐 4. Internet Connectivity

A weak or unstable internet connection can interfere with file uploads. Ensure you have a stable connection, preferably over Wi-Fi, to facilitate successful uploads.​TechYouLike

🧹 5. Clear WhatsApp Cache

Corrupted cache data can cause issues with file uploads. Clearing the cache can resolve such problems:​Cisco Community+1Indian Tech Hunter+1

  • On Android:

    1. Go to Settings > Apps > WhatsApp.

    2. Tap Storage.

    3. Tap Clear Cache.​Indian Tech Hunter

Note: Clearing the cache will not delete your chats or media.​Indian Tech Hunter

🔄 6. Try a Different Browser or Device

If you're using WhatsApp Web, browser-specific issues might be causing the problem. Try accessing WhatsApp Web in a different browser or on a different device to see if the issue persists.​Guiding Tech+1YouTube+1

🛠️ 7. Check MIME Type and File Integrity

Ensure that the file's MIME type matches its actual content type. You can use command-line tools to verify the MIME type:​GitHub

  • On Unix/macOS:

bash
  file -I rejected-file.mov

  • On Windows:

powershell
  Get-Content rejected-file.mov -Raw | Format-Hex

If the MIME type doesn't match the file's content, consider converting the file to the correct format.​

If you've checked all the above and the issue persists, please provide more details about the file type and size, and any error messages received, so I can assist you further.

The error message ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED typically means that your frontend is trying to make a request to http://localhost:3000/upload, but your server isn't running on that port, or there is an issue with the server connection.

Here's what you can do:

1. Ensure Server is Running on the Correct Port

  • React (frontend) is running on port 3000 (as you indicated).

  • The backend (Express server) should run on a different port (e.g., port 5000).

In your server.js, the port is set like this:

js
const port = process.env.PORT || 5000;

So, your backend should be accessible at http://localhost:5000.

2. Fix Frontend URL in uploadFile

In your frontend code, you are trying to make a POST request to http://localhost:3000/upload, but the server is running on port 5000. Change the URL to http://localhost:5000/upload in the uploadFile function.

Update your uploadFile function in send.jsx:

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  const formData = new FormData();
  formData.append("file", file);

  try {
    const response = await fetch("http://localhost:5000/upload", {  // Changed port to 5000
      method: "POST",
      body: formData,
    });

    const data = await response.json();
    return data.fileUrl;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error uploading file:", error);
  }
};

3. Check if Backend is Running

Make sure your backend is running on localhost:5000. If you haven’t started the server yet, you can do so by running the following in your terminal:

bash
node server.js

It should print something like this:

bash
Server running on port 5000

4. Check CORS Configuration

Make sure that your CORS setup on the backend allows requests from the React frontend (running on localhost:3000).

In server.js, ensure the CORS is set up correctly:

js
app.use(cors({ origin: "http://localhost:3000" }));

5. Ensure Both Frontend and Backend are Running

  • Frontend (React): npm start (or yarn start if you're using Yarn) on port 3000.

  • Backend (Node/Express): node server.js on port 5000.

Recap of Fixes:

  • Change fetch URL in uploadFile to http://localhost:5000/upload.

  • Start your backend server on port 5000 (node server.js).

  • Verify CORS settings are correct in server.js.

Once these steps are followed, the ERR_CONNECTION_REFUSED error should be resolved! Let me know if you need further clarification.

ChatGPT said:

It sounds like there's an issue where the URL is not being generated properly or the backend is not returning the expected file URL after the upload. Let’s troubleshoot step by step:

1. Ensure Your Backend Returns a Proper URL

First, let’s ensure that your backend (Node/Express server) is correctly handling the file upload and returning a URL for the uploaded file.

In your backend code (server.js), make sure that after the file is uploaded, you're sending a response with the file URL. Here’s an example of what the backend might look like for file upload using multer:

Backend Code (File Upload in server.js)

js
const express = require('express');
const cors = require('cors');
const multer = require('multer');
const path = require('path');
const fs = require('fs');

const app = express();
const port = 5000; // Ensure your server is on a different port (5000)

app.use(cors()); // This allows your frontend to talk to your backend

// Set up multer for file upload
const storage = multer.diskStorage({
  destination: (req, file, cb) => {
    cb(null, './uploads'); // Change this to your preferred upload folder
  },
  filename: (req, file, cb) => {
    cb(null, Date.now() + path.extname(file.originalname)); // Unique filename
  },
});

const upload = multer({ storage: storage });

app.post('/upload', upload.single('file'), (req, res) => {
  // Ensure the file was uploaded successfully
  if (!req.file) {
    return res.status(400).send('No file uploaded');
  }

  const fileUrl = `http://localhost:5000/uploads/${req.file.filename}`;

  // Return the file URL in the response
  res.json({ fileUrl });
});

app.listen(port, () => {
  console.log(`Server running on port ${port}`);
});

Key Points:

  1. File Upload Folder: In the code above, the uploads folder is where files will be stored. Make sure this folder exists in your project directory, or create it manually.

  2. Returning File URL: After the file is uploaded, the backend sends back the file URL like this: http://localhost:5000/uploads/filename.extension.

2. Check if the File is Being Uploaded Correctly

When you try uploading the file, check the backend logs to ensure:

  • The file is uploaded correctly (look for any errors in the backend console).

  • The backend is responding with the correct file URL.

For debugging, you can log the req.file to see if it's received correctly:

js
console.log(req.file);  // Log the uploaded file information

3. Ensure File Path is Correct

Ensure that you are sending the request to the correct URL on the frontend, and the backend is properly set up to handle file requests at http://localhost:5000/upload.

4. Frontend (Check the Response from Upload)

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  const formData = new FormData();

  try {
    const response = await fetch("http://localhost:5000/upload", {
      method: "POST",
      body: formData,
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('File upload failed');
    }

    const data = await response.json();
    console.log('File URL:', data.fileUrl);  // Log the URL to see if it's returned correctly
    return data.fileUrl;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error uploading file:", error);
  }
};

5. Check the URL in the Frontend

Once the file is uploaded, you should be getting a URL (e.g., http://localhost:5000/uploads/filename.extension). This URL will be used to share the file or download it. If it’s not generating, make sure:

  • The backend is returning the file URL correctly.

  • The frontend is correctly processing this URL.

Debugging the Problem:

  1. Check the Network Tab: In your browser's developer tools, open the "Network" tab and look at the request to /upload. Check the response to see if it contains the expected fileUrl. If the response is empty or has an error message, that's where the problem lies.

  2. Log the Errors: If you're seeing "Error uploading URL" or some similar message, it’s likely an issue in the code that processes the file URL after upload. If you can share the exact error, it will help pinpoint the issue.

6. Check if File Upload Works Locally

Finally, you can test the file upload manually using a tool like Postman or cURL to make sure the backend is correctly handling the file upload.

Using cURL:

bash

If you get a response with a fileUrl, it means the backend is working, and the problem is likely on the frontend.

Conclusion:

  • Ensure your backend is correctly handling the file upload and returning the file URL.

  • On the frontend, log the file URL returned from the backend and make sure the correct URL is being used for sharing or downloading the file.

  • Double-check the paths and server configurations to ensure both frontend and backend are working properly together.

Your current server-side code for file uploading looks solid overall, but there are a few things we can double-check to ensure everything works correctly. Let's break it down and check everything from the setup to how the server handles the file upload and serves the files.

1. Directory Creation for Uploads

You are using fs.existsSync(uploadsDir) to check if the "Uploads" directory exists, and if not, you create it. This is a good approach. Make sure the server has proper write permissions to create directories and store files.

2. Static File Serving

You're using app.use("/uploads", express.static(path.join(__dirname, "Uploads"))); to serve static files. This means files that are uploaded will be accessible via http://localhost:<port>/uploads/<filename>, which is correctly configured.

3. File Size and Type Validation

You're limiting the file size to 500MB, which is a large size. Just ensure this aligns with your project’s requirements. You're also validating file types to only allow PDFs, PNGs, and DOCXs. This looks good, as it prevents uploading of unsupported file types.

4. Generating a Unique Filename

The unique filename generated by combining the current timestamp with a random number is a good approach to prevent naming conflicts. You can leave this as is.

5. Error Handling

Your error handling in the /upload route is appropriate. You're checking if a file is uploaded and handling errors gracefully. The use of try/catch blocks ensures any unexpected errors are caught.

6. Returning the File URL

Once the file is uploaded successfully, you're generating a URL like http://localhost:<port>/uploads/<filename>. This URL will be returned to the frontend, which should allow users to access or download the uploaded file. Ensure that the frontend is correctly handling this returned URL.

What to Check

1. Ensure the Uploads Folder Exists

Make sure the "Uploads" folder exists and the server has write permissions. You can double-check this by creating the folder manually if needed.

    console.error("Error uploading file:", error);
  }
};

This frontend code sends the file to the backend and expects a JSON response with the fileUrl. Make sure you're logging the response to confirm you're getting the correct URL.

4. Handling CORS

You’ve already added CORS for http://localhost:3000 to allow your React frontend to talk to the backend. If your frontend is hosted on a different port or domain, you'll need to adjust the CORS configuration.

js
app.use(cors({ origin: "http://localhost:3000" }));

Make sure this matches the URL your frontend is running on. If you're using a different port or environment, update it accordingly.

Using Postman:

  1. Set the method to POST and the URL to http://localhost:5000/upload.

  2. Under the "Body" tab, choose "form-data" and add a field called file with the type file, then select a file to upload.

Using cURL:

bash
curl -X POST -F "file=@yourfile.png" http://localhost:5000/upload

Check if you get a response with a fileUrl. If the backend works correctly with Postman or cURL but not through the frontend, the issue might be in the frontend code or communication.

6. Server Logs

Make sure your server logs are providing helpful information. If there’s any issue with the upload (like an unsupported file type or file size), check the logs for detailed error messages.

Summary

  1. Ensure the Uploads directory exists and has proper write permissions.

  2. Make sure the frontend is correctly handling the file upload and the response (log the fileUrl).

  3. Test the upload with Postman or cURL to ensure the backend works as expected.

  4. Check the Network tab in your browser’s developer tools for any issues with the request/response.

If everything works on the backend and Postman but still fails on the frontend, we can dive deeper into the frontend code or other networking issues. Let me know how it goes!

You said:
Or could it e the case like frontend can't connect with backend? short ans
ChatGPT said:

Yes, it could be an issue where the frontend can't connect to the backend. This can happen due to:

  1. CORS Issues: Ensure CORS is properly configured on the backend to allow requests from the frontend.

  2. Wrong API URL: Verify the URL in your frontend matches the backend (e.g., http://localhost:5000/upload).

  3. Network/Port Issues: If the backend is running on a different port or domain, the frontend might not be able to reach it.

Check your browser’s Network tab for any connection errors or CORS issues.

You said:
in frontend i should import server file? short ans
ChatGPT said:

No, you should not import the server file in the frontend. Instead, the frontend should make HTTP requests (e.g., using fetch or axios) to the backend API endpoints (e.g., http://localhost:5000/upload).

You said:
yes, there is an upload folder present in server folder... in that one there are several coded files are present (let me give one for more transparency):
ChatGPT said:

It seems like you're referring to several files inside the Uploads folder on your server, and you'd like to ensure that the upload functionality works correctly.

You don’t need to modify the Uploads folder or its contents directly. The key thing is that the server’s upload endpoint should correctly handle file uploads, as you've already set up in your server.js file.

However, if you want to ensure that files are being uploaded to the correct directory and are being served correctly, here are a few things to keep in mind:

  1. Check if the Uploads folder exists: This should be checked and automatically created by the server.js when the server starts up. If the folder doesn’t exist, the server will create it for you.

  2. Access the uploaded files: Files uploaded through the /upload endpoint are stored in the Uploads folder. They should be publicly accessible via the http://localhost:5000/uploads/ URL, as specified in your server.js.

If you'd like to share the code for one of the files inside the Uploads folder or provide more specific details, feel free to do so! I'll be happy to help clarify how to handle them or diagnose any issues related to uploads.

But in general, files within the Uploads folder should just be uploaded automatically when using the server's API without needing any manual intervention.

�������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������������� ChatGPT said:

​

The message you submitted was too long, please reload the conversation and submit something shorter.

You said:
could you see the above encoded file?
ChatGPT said:

It looks like you're trying to share the contents of a file for me to review. However, I don't see any file uploaded or shared in your message.

Could you please either:

  1. Paste the content of the file directly here (if it's not too large), or

  2. Upload the file so I can take a look?

This way, I can better understand the situation and help you more effectively!

You said:
the file was too long let's leave it, point is upload folder contains encoded files rn... the files are generating tho. but the url counldn't?
ChatGPT said:

Got it! If the files are being generated in the Uploads folder but the URLs aren't working, here are a few things to check:

1. Server Path Configuration

Make sure that the path you're using to serve the static files is correctly configured. In your code, you're using:

javascript
app.use("/uploads", express.static(path.join(__dirname, "Uploads")));

This should serve the files correctly as long as the Uploads folder is located in the root of the project directory, and the files are being saved in that folder.

Check:

  • Verify the file exists in Uploads/ after the upload.

  • Double-check the URL you're trying to access the files with. For example, if a file is uploaded as file123.png, the URL should be: http://localhost:5000/uploads/file123.png.

2. File Permissions

Ensure the server has the proper permissions to serve files from the Uploads folder. In some cases, the web server may not have permission to access certain files or folders.

Check:

  • Ensure the server process has read access to the files in the Uploads folder.

3. File URL Generation

In your backend code, you're generating the URL as:

javascript
const fileUrl = `http://localhost:${port}/uploads/${req.file.filename}`;

Ensure that the req.file.filename is correct, and the generated URL corresponds to the actual file.

Check:

  • Log the fileUrl value in the backend to make sure it's correct (i.e., it's returning the right file name and path).

4. Accessing the File

When you try to access the file via the generated URL, ensure that:

  • The server is running, and the uploads route is working.

  • You're accessing the URL correctly (e.g., http://localhost:5000/uploads/file123.png).

  • There are no typos in the file name or URL.

5. Cross-Origin Resource Sharing (CORS)

Since you're making requests from a frontend (possibly on localhost:3000), ensure that your backend has the proper CORS configuration to allow requests from the frontend.

It seems like you have CORS configured already:

javascript
app.use(cors({ origin: "http://localhost:3000" }));

This should work as long as the frontend is running on localhost:3000.

Quick Steps to Debug:

  1. Log File URL in Backend: Add a log right after generating the file URL to ensure it's correct.

    javascript
    console.log('File URL:', fileUrl);

  1. Ensure Upload Completes Before Using File URL On the frontend, ensure that the file upload is fully completed and the server responds with the file URL before trying to use it in your application (e.g., for sharing).

    Here's a quick example of how you can handle the file upload and URL assignment properly:

    javascript
    // Frontend (React example)
const handleFileUpload = async (event) => {
  const formData = new FormData();
  formData.append('file', event.target.files[0]);

  try {
    // Disable sharing button until upload completes
    setIsUploading(true);

    const response = await fetch('http://localhost:5000/upload', {
      method: 'POST',
      body: formData,
    });

    if (!response.ok) {
      throw new Error('File upload failed');
    }

    const data = await response.json();
    setFileUrl(data.fileUrl); // Store the file URL for later use
  } catch (error) {
    console.error('Upload failed:', error);
    // Handle error here
  } finally {
    setIsUploading(false); // Re-enable the share button after upload
  }
};

    • Explanation: In the example above, the setIsUploading(true) disables the sharing button or similar UI elements while the file is uploading, preventing users from trying to interact with the uploaded file until it’s fully available.

    javascript
    app.post("/upload", upload.single("file"), (req, res) => {

    return res.status(400).json({ error: "No file uploaded" });

  const fileUrl = `http://localhost:${port}/uploads/${req.file.filename}`;
  console.log("File uploaded and accessible at: ", fileUrl);

  res.json({ fileUrl }); // Ensure that the file URL is returned correctly
});

  3. Check File Size and Server Load: If the files are larger (or the server is under load), it might be causing delays. You can log the time taken to upload a file to see if it's a performance issue:

    javascript
    console.log('Upload started at: ', Date.now());
// After upload process
console.log('Upload completed at: ', Date.now());

  4. React: Async Handling and State Management If you’re using React, ensure that the state reflects the uploaded file URL only after the upload is complete, and don’t trigger rendering before the upload is fully done.

  5. Check for Uncaught Errors in the Frontend: Sometimes the UI might not be updating because of unhandled errors. Ensure you are catching all errors and displaying appropriate messages.

Quick Debug Checklist:

  • Log timestamps for both upload start and completion to identify any delay.

  • Ensure synchronous flow: The frontend should wait for the upload response before using the file URL.

  • Check the network tab in developer tools to see if the request/response is slow or if there are network issues.

  • Check server logs to verify if the file upload process is completing successfully, or if it's timing out or failing before the URL is returned.

🔁 What Happens in Send.jsx When You Share a File:

In the uploadFile function:

js
const uploadFile = async (file) => {
  const formData = new FormData();
  formData.append("file", file);

  try {
    const response = await fetch("http://localhost:3000/upload", {
      method: "POST",
      body: formData,
    });

    return data.fileUrl;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error uploading file:", error);
  }
};

✅ What is actually sent to the backend:

  • A POST request is made to http://localhost:3000/upload

  • The body contains a FormData object with a single key: "file"

  • The value of "file" is a Blob object (i.e. the file content in memory: PDF, PNG, or DOCX) that was previously generated in the frontend (e.g. using jsPDF, html2canvas, or docx library)

🎯 Key Insight: What data is sent?

  • 🔐 Only the file itself is sent — as a multipart/form-data POST

  • ❌ No metadata like filename, invoiceNumber, etc., unless explicitly added to the FormData

Example if you wanted to send metadata:

js
formData.append("invoiceNumber", data.invoiceNumber);
formData.append("file", file);

But in your current code: only the file blob is sent.

💥 Likely Problem (based on your earlier error):

You're sending the file to port 3000 (http://localhost:3000/upload), which is usually your React frontend, not the backend.

Your backend runs on port 5000, so the correct line should be:

js
const response = await fetch("http://localhost:5000/upload", {
  method: "POST",
  body: formData,
});

✅ Summary:

What is sent to the backend?

What is wrong?

  • You're accidentally posting to port 3000 (frontend), not 5000 (your backend that handles uploads)

That's a sharp observation — you're absolutely right to question this. Let's break it down:

🔄 Why not just send the already downloaded file to the backend?

✅ Pros of sending the downloaded file:

  1. Accurate file name and format:
    The file already has the correct name (invoice-123.pdf, etc.) and is finalized by the client.

  2. Guaranteed content:
    You know exactly what the file looks like because it's the one you just downloaded or generated.

  3. Reduces frontend complexity:
    No need to regenerate a blob just for upload — you can directly read the existing file.

  4. Better for consistency:
    The shared version matches exactly with what was downloaded by the user.

⚠️ Cons / Considerations:

  1. Browser security:
    Browsers don't allow direct access to a downloaded file from disk due to sandboxing — you'd have to:

    • Let the user manually select it again, or

    • Keep the file in memory before saving (i.e., reuse the same blob that was just downloaded)

  2. Storage management:
    If you're auto-downloading the file and also uploading it, you're doing the same work twice — better to skip saving locally if you're just uploading.

  3. Unnecessary step:
    You're already generating the blob in memory to download — so just reuse that blob and upload it to the backend.

✅ Best Practice (Your Case):

You're doing this correctly already:

  • You generate the file (PDF/DOCX/PNG) in memory

  • You save it locally with saveAs(blob, ...)

  • You then reuse the same blob to upload

So instead of re-downloading and sending later, you're just sending it once in memory — that’s cleaner and faster.

🔚 Final Thought:

Yes, your logic is solid — but from a technical/browser perspective, uploading the in-memory blob is the best option. It ensures:

  • Accuracy

  • Performance

  • Avoids needing user interaction again

  • Or use the originalname with some safe cleanup instead of randomizing

cb(null, `${Date.now()}-${file.originalname}`);

In backend:

  try {

    return data.fileUrl;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Error uploading file:", error);
    return null;
  }
};

✅ Backend Upload Setup (server.js)

Ensure this part of your Multer config is like this:

js
const storage = multer.diskStorage({
  destination: (req, file, cb) => {
    cb(null, "Uploads/");
  },
  filename: (req, file, cb) => {
    const timestamp = Date.now();
    const safeName = file.originalname.replace(/\s+/g, "_"); // remove spaces
    cb(null, `${timestamp}-${safeName}`); // ✅ Preserves file type
  },
});

Your /upload route remains the same:

js
app.post("/upload", upload.single("file"), (req, res) => {
  try {
    if (!req.file) {
      return res.status(400).json({ error: "No file uploaded" });
    }

    const fileUrl = `http://localhost:${port}/uploads/${req.file.filename}`;

    res.json({ fileUrl }); // ✅ Returns usable URL
  } catch (error) {
    console.error("Upload error:", error);
    res.status(500).json({ error: "Failed to upload file" });
  }
});
